awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Thermal Energy Recovery, Refrigeration and Management (TERRM)
awd_abstract_narration:
The ever-growing energy demand, escalating energy prices, and environmental concerns compel us to look for cleaner and more sustainable energy sources. Meanwhile, the need of portable power or on-demand production of electrical power using locally available energy sources demands the development of compact, efficient and cost-effective power generators. Economically viable technologies for recovering and transferring waste heat generated by devices and integrating these thermal management solutions will create the opportunity to develop new industries and expand the US economy. The growing demand for high-performance miniaturized electronics has accelerated the need to design and develop compact heat management solutions that are silent, lightweight and comprised of materials that can be recycled. The Engineering Research Center for Thermal Energy Recovery, Refrigeration and Management (TERRM) addresses the National Grand Challenge to ?Restore and Improve Urban Infrastructure? by providing foundational technologies required for thermal energy recovery, solid-state refrigeration, distributed energy supply and advanced manufacturing. It builds on the foundation provided by NSF?s big ideas covering ?harnessing data revolution?, ?mid-scale research infrastructure?, and ?quantum leap?. The ERC testbeds will transform the way we design thermal energy based distributed electric generation systems. 

The requested funding will be used to conduct targeted national and international events to build a comprehensive team related to TERRM. Workshops, site visits, industry partnerships and conference sessions will provide a systematic roadmap for thermal system design, manufacturing, testing and implementation. Planning stage events will provide lists of grand challenges and time-dependent opportunities which will assist in the development of thrusts targeting basic physics, working principles, performance measurements, materials, and devices. During the planning phase, the goal will be to identify the industrial base, technology roadmap, technology barriers, regulations and standards, commercialization partners, and intellectual property in all targeted areas of TERRM. Advanced system designs for thermal management will be identified through extensive interactions with industry partners. The planning grant activities will build a multi-disciplinary engineering team to address the technology barriers identified during the planning workshop and industrial visits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ever-growing energy demand, escalating energy prices, and environmental concerns compel us to look for cleaner and more sustainable ways of addressing societal needs and resolving grand challenges. There is a tremendous amount of electrical energy utilized in thermal management in residential spaces, transportation, and industrial manufacturing. The center planning activities started with the discussions on how to transform the way we design thermal energy management systems. These discussions led to development of a center concept that reimagines, reinvents, and repurposes paint to address thermal management, climate crisis, health threats, and social inequality, which are among the greatest challenges facing our society. It builds on the foundation provided by NSFs big ideas covering harnessing data revolution, mid-scale research infrastructure, and quantum leap. Workshops, site visits, industry partnerships and online sessions provided a systematic roadmap for thermal system design, manufacturing, testing and implementation. Today paint probably occupies the largest surface area around us among any engineered systems. There is massive potential and impact if new functionalities can be included in the paints. The overarching themes that emerged during the workshops, site visits, and group discussions are: (1) fundamental understanding of selective and active paint material properties and their degradation mechanisms; (2) development of scalable and cost-effective paint-based technologies for cooling and healthy environment; (3) integration of the technologies into building, industrial and transportation systems; and (4) adoption of the technologies at the community, urban, and earth scales. Recent demonstrations by the researchers involved in the planning workshop have shown that radiative cooling paints can cool surfaces below the ambient temperature without consuming power. Compared to conventional air conditioners that cool down interior space but heat up their surroundings (urban heat island effect) and the earth, the radiative cooling paint cools down both the interior space and the earth by directly sending the heat to deep space. The enabling scientific breakthroughs will be new fundamental understanding of selective optical properties, dynamic interactions with the environment, and degradation mechanisms, via developing new computational and machine learning models tailored for paints. In some scenarios, the team found attractive to couple the paint-based solutions with other potential technical advances such as piezoelectrics, thermoelectrics and thermochromics. To exemplify, in the past decades, researchers have developed various methods to directly print thermoelectric devices in conformal or thin film format. Combined with the advanced techniques of printing, printable thermoelectric devices can greatly broaden the cooling applications domain. Equally important, flexible high performance thermoelectric coating-based devices can reduce the consumption of unrecoverable energy resources. Enabling engineering breakthroughs will occur via scalable, low cost, and sustainable synthesis and manufacturing. Systems demonstration and integration of these technologies, coupled with concurrent research on adoption, will reveal unprecedented energy, health, and climate benefits while assessing and overcoming potential economic, social, and regulatory barriers towards commercialization. The team has identified the industrial base, technology roadmap, technology barriers, regulations and standards, commercialization partners, and intellectual property in all targeted areas of the center concept. Advanced system designs for thermal management have been identified through extensive interactions with industry partners. The planning grant activities led to the buildup of multidisciplinary engineering team to address the technology barriers identified during the planning workshop and site visits.

The planned center concept will benefit society on the broadest scale, with most significant impacts on underprivileged communities without access to otherwise expensive air conditioning or air purification. Cooling paints can be used in other wide-ranging applications including food and vaccine preservation. It is estimated that painting 1-2% of the earth's surface with radiative cooling paints could reduce warming of the earth. The research conducted in the center will transform paint and coating technologies into a new and exciting industry, while training a diverse workforce of the next generation of leaders and innovators in science and technology. Students will gain a unique and multidisciplinary skillset currently unavailable in industry, by exposure to fundamental new concepts and materials, scalable synthesis and manufacturing, testing in real-world sites, and entrepreneurship and global impact. The center will create a diverse, inclusive innovation ecosystem by actively recruiting faculty, staff, postdocs, students, K-12 participants, and partners from underrepresented groups, by creating an environment that cultivates a sense of belonging and encourages full participation by all center members, and by routinely evaluating progress and initiating programming changes to improve outcomes as the center evolves.
